body:
If you have a project that has a quota and a limitrange:

```
apiVersion: v1
items:
- apiVersion: v1
  kind: ResourceQuota
  metadata:
    creationTimestamp: 2015-11-03T15:42:46Z
    name: sinatra-quota
    namespace: sinatra
    resourceVersion: "2113"
    selfLink: /api/v1/namespaces/sinatra/resourcequotas/sinatra-quota
    uid: 876c921f-8241-11e5-a64b-525400b33d1d
  spec:
    hard:
      cpu: 200m
      memory: 512Mi
      pods: "3"
      replicationcontrollers: "3"
      resourcequotas: "1"
      services: "3"
  status:
    hard:
      cpu: 200m
      memory: 512Mi
      pods: "3"
      replicationcontrollers: "3"
      resourcequotas: "1"
      services: "3"
    used:
      cpu: 100m
      memory: 100Mi
      pods: "1"
      replicationcontrollers: "2"
      resourcequotas: "1"
      services: "1"
- apiVersion: v1
  kind: LimitRange
  metadata:
    creationTimestamp: 2015-11-03T15:42:46Z
    name: sinatra-limits
    namespace: sinatra
    resourceVersion: "1570"
    selfLink: /api/v1/namespaces/sinatra/limitranges/sinatra-limits
    uid: 87a02697-8241-11e5-a64b-525400b33d1d
  spec:
    limits:
    - max:
        cpu: 500m
        memory: 750Mi
      min:
        cpu: 10m
        memory: 5Mi
      type: Pod
    - default:
        cpu: 100m
        memory: 100Mi
      defaultRequest:
        cpu: 100m
        memory: 100Mi
      max:
        cpu: 500m
        memory: 750Mi
      min:
        cpu: 10m
        memory: 5Mi
      type: Container
kind: List
metadata: {}
```

When you try to deploy a new pod, the default (from the limitrange) is inherited by the deployer pod. In this case, 100m cpu.

So, if you already have 2 pods scheduled (using 200m cpu), you are at quota/limit. Then, when the deployer tries to deploy something else, you get this error:

```
Error creating: Pod "ruby-example-2-" is forbidden: unable to admit pod without exceeding quota for resource cpu:  limited to 200m but require 300m to succeed.
```

If you read this error, on the surface it seems to indicate the wrong thing. It talks about "unable to admit pod" and then says "limited to 200m".

The reality is that the **project** is limited to 200m of total CPU, and we're already using that much. Scheduling this pod (whose requirement is 100m) would result in a total scheduled amount of 300m, which is over quota.

Perhaps a different wording could be something like:

```
Error creating: Pod "ruby-example-2-" is forbidden: quota exceeded for resource cpu:  project limited to 200m, current usage is 200m, pod requires 100m
```

Or more generally, the format of:

```
project limit is X, current usage is Y, and you're asking for Z more
```
title: pod quota cpu limit exceeded message is confusing
